displayed_text:
Post

How to store my insulin while going on a trip? Im planing with my boyfriend to go on a trip for a whole month, mostly camping but i dont know whats the best way to keep my insulin in a cold enviroment. Do you have any recomendation for a good portable cooler??

Comments:

Comment 1: Frio packs EDIT: I took Frio wallets up Mt Kilimanjaro and they kept my insulin at the right temperature even when faced with sub zero at night and 30°C at sea level, and all you need to refresh/recharge them is some water - just dunk them

Comment 2: I have a Dometic cooler. It can be powered off of different power sources and has more precise temperature control than a mini fridge. Good for both travel and for an emergency. Also, make sure your Rx is up to date before your trip. That way, if you need an emergency refill, it will be easier to get.

Comment 3: Insulin is shelf stable for about a month at room temp. It will lose a bit of potency (5%ish max) over the month, but it’s no different from having a vial of R and NPH in an old style kit. Bring enough alcohol swabs to ensure clean tops and clean sites. Avoid keeping insulin in the sun and try to keep it’s bag in the shade. I’ve used something like a men’s night bag, similar to a toiletries bag but usually leather or heavy cloth to protect from shaving razors. It might be a good idea to put insulin in it’s own ziplock inside of whatever bag you end up using. In fact, it might be worth putting all medical supplies in a water tight ziplock inside the bag as a precaution. Annoying to open is better than infections from pond water logged supplies. Good luck!

Comment 4: You can get insulin coolers on amazon

Comment 5: I take out a bottle and keep it out of the fridge for a month. No issues for the past 5years

Comment 6: Where in the world are you going? What month of the year? Unopened insulin is pretty hardy, and in the right environment will store a long time.

span_annotations.span: Frio packs EDIT: I took Frio wallets up Mt Kilimanjaro and they kept my insulin at the right temperature even when faced with sub zero at night and 30°C at sea level, and all you need to refresh/recharge them is some water - just dunk them

I have a Dometic cooler. It can be powered off of different power sources and has more precise temperature control than a mini fridge. Good for both travel and for an emergency.

Also, make sure your Rx is up to date before your trip. That way, if you need an emergency refill, it will be easier to get.

Insulin is shelf stable for about a month at room temp. It will lose a bit of potency (5%ish max) over the month, but it’s no different from having a vial of R and NPH in an old style kit. 

Bring enough alcohol swabs to ensure clean tops and clean sites. 

Avoid keeping insulin in the sun and try to keep it’s bag in the shade.

I’ve used something like a men’s night bag, similar to a toiletries bag but usually leather or heavy cloth to protect from shaving razors. 

It might be a good idea to put insulin in it’s own ziplock inside of whatever bag you end up using. In fact, it might be worth putting all medical supplies in a water tight ziplock inside the bag as a precaution. Annoying to open is better than infections from pond water logged supplies.

Good luck!
I take out a bottle and keep it out of the fridge for a month. No issues for the past 5years
Where in the world are you going? What month of the year? Unopened insulin is pretty hardy, and in the right environment will store a long time.

displayed_text:
Post

Can I actually drink milkshake? For valentines, my boyfriend and I went to McDonald's because we're two young men in our early twenties and late teens, and therefore, we are broke as fuck. It was still romantic, despite the one billion children in the restaurant. While deciding what to order, I came across milkshakes. And I haven't had a milkshake since 2017, when I was diagnosed with t1. My boyfriend asked me if I can actually drink that, since I've told him that I can't drink sugary stuff (unless they contain alcohol, hallelujah) and I realised I'd never asked my dietician about that. So I drank coke zero instead, and I'm getting really tired of that. So so SO tired of coke zero. Can I have milkshakes? Because honestly I miss milkshakes so much. They're my guilty pleasure. I need them back in my life. How do pen users take enough insulin for milkshakes? Is milkshake on the list of "forbidden snacks"? Please keep yourselves from preaching your low carb, keto, Mars soil only diets and whatnot. I'm struggling to stay above the underweight limit. A change in diet is not what I need right now. Thank you for your understanding.

Comments:

Comment 1: Rejoice! Drink a shake! Now, not all shakes are created equal. McDonald's vanilla shakes (small) tip the scale at nearly 80g of carbs! So, just be sure to calculate the appropriate units of your fast-acting insulin. And happy Valentine's Day to you and your boyfriend! ❤️🏳️‍🌈

Comment 2: how have you had diabetes for 3 years and not know that you can drink sugary things? you sweet summer child. you can have whatever you want as long as you count the carbs and take the correct amount of insulin!

Comment 3: Short answer. Yes... I use a pump so I handle milkshakes and stuff differently. But! For sugary drinks like that, if I had to inject, I would prebolus at least 20 minutes in advance. Then freely drink it. That way I make sure the insulin is acting in me and dropping me, at the same time stay in range by drinking the milkshake

Comment 4: Go ahead a splurge! Just make sure you dose for it. My son gets a treat once a month and it’s all trial and error. Some are harder to figure out than others but you won’t know until you try. Happy Valentines Day!

Comment 5: You came here to ask if you can have a milkshake but literally banned people against high sugar items from answering, so, you just wanted people to validate your decision, so drink the milkshake. Liquid sugar is extremely hard to bolus for you’re gonna need to watch yourself carefully. Good luck.

Comment 6: I remember feeling like that for the first few years after my diagnosis. Drink the milkshake, just monitor a little more than normal if you don’t have a cgm. You may need to take the insulin in split doses since you mentioned you are on pens, but you can responsibly have a milkshake.

Comment 7: Mini shakes from sonic are a serious weakness of mine - they’re small enough that the carb load isn’t too insane 👍

Comment 8: A traditional ice cream shake from McDonalds can be 60-100 grams of carbs: https://www.mcdonalds.com/us/en-us/product/vanilla-shake-large.html (toggle the sizes) can you? Yes. Do you want to eat 1/2-2/3 of your daily carb load in one item? It's not a good idea, but you can. Interestingly enough, because of the fat content, it will not spike as badly, but it will spike for longer (order of 5-6 hours as opposed to 2). Sugary soda (no fat) spikes it higher, faster - in some ways, it is more dangerous.

span_annotations.span: had diabetes for 3 years and not know that you can drink sugary things? you sweet summer child. you can have whatever you want as long as you count the carbs and take the correct amount of insulin!

displayed_text:
Post

how do you get tested for type 1 or type 2?

Comments:

Comment 1: Have y'all had C-peptide and HbA1c tests done? Those are the standard diagnostic tests.

Comment 2: They tested for GAD65 antibodies for me to confirm it’s type 1

Comment 3: I got an antibody test done and confirmed type 1. Although apparently symptoms for type 1 and type 2 can have some variation so they could also be doing that.

Comment 4: She needs to be seen by an endocrinologist. I was initially diagnosed by a family practice doc as T2 even though both my mother and my son are T1. Turns out I have LADA which is an autoimmune type that progresses slower than standard T1 and usually appears after age 30. I had a c peptide done initially and my results were within the normal range despite a high A1C and fasting glucose of over 300. Once I saw an endocrinologist I was immediately started on insulin and tested for GAD and Islet antibodies. Please have her ask for a referral as some types of oral meds can actually speed up the destruction of beta cells in autoimmune diabetes. EDIT: I had the same problem with getting in to an endocrinologist even with my GP’s referral. I couldn’t get an appointment until like 4 months out! A fantastic receptionist suggested I call at least weekly to check for any cancelations. I ended up getting in two weeks later. This route might be worth a shot. EDIT #2: If she does request a c peptide and the results come back normal they can still be interpreted for type. T2’s often have an elevated or high normal c peptide level whereas autoimmune tends to be low or low normal. Feel free to message me; I’m happy to help in any way I can.

Comment 5: I don’t really know about type 2... but as a type-1 I remember that they took a blood sample cause I had severe head aches for about a week or so. Then they told me that I could go home and they would call me. The next morning they called me and said right as I was going to eat breakfast that I should get there ASAP and I shouldn’t eat anything and from there on they just took an HbA1C

Comment 6: They need to run a full metabolic panel, c-peptide, and GAD antibody tests. If the doctor refuses, make sure to ask that they document their refusal in her chart. Never ever be afraid to ask for a second opinion.

span_annotations.span: Have y'all had C-peptide and HbA1c tests done? Those are the standard diagnostic tests.
They tested for GAD65 antibodies for me to confirm it’s type 1
I got an antibody test done and confirmed type 1. Although apparently symptoms for type 1 and type 2 can have some variation so they could also be doin

She needs to be seen by an endocrinologist.  I was initially diagnosed by a family practice doc as T2 even though both my mother and my son are T1.

Turns out I have LADA which is an autoimmune type that progresses slower than standard T1 and usually appears after age 30.

I had a c peptide done initially and my results were within the normal range despite a high A1C and fasting glucose of over 300.

Once I saw an endocrinologist I was immediately started on insulin and tested for GAD and Islet antibodies.

Please have her ask for a referral as some types of oral meds can actually speed up the destruction of beta cells in autoimmune diabetes.

EDIT:  I had the same problem with getting in to an endocrinologist even with my GP’s referral.  I couldn’t get an appointment until like 4 months out!  A fantastic receptionist suggested I call at least weekly to check for any cancelations.  I ended up getting in two weeks later.  This route might be worth a shot.

EDIT #2:  If she does request a c peptide and the results come back normal they can still be interpreted for type.  T2’s often have an elevated or high normal c peptide level whereas autoimmune tends to be low or low normal.  Feel free to message me; I’m happy to help in any way I can.

They need to run a full metabolic panel, c-peptide, and GAD antibody tests. If the doctor refuses, make sure to ask that they document their refusal in her chart. Never ever be afraid to ask for a second opinion

displayed_text:
Post

How to stop spikes Every single time I eat damn near anything I spike very quickly, the issue is is that when I spike I don’t come back down like at all. So all I can do is just sit and watch my blood sugar go up. I feel like I would have to starve myself in order to keep my blood sugars at a level I feel ok at. What’s something you guys do to avoid the spikes after eating?

Comments:

Comment 1: Take a walk.

Comment 2: I can’t always avoid them but I find the timing is important-I have a list of things I know how long to pre bolus for or extend my bolus. So somethings I get right but some no. If I find I’m not coming down then correction doses.

Comment 3: What time did you bolus vs what time did you eat? What is your blood sugar 4hrs post injection(for the meal)? What did you eat? Did you weigh it or guesstimate the carb content? How does your blood sugar get back in range? Do you have to give a correction bolus to get back in range? 🫶💙

Comment 4: We need more info. It’s normal to spike after eating - and it depends where you started. If you need a breather, low carb = less insulin which = fewer spikes.

Comment 5: Judging by that graph, you’re running fairly high the entire time. Have you done basal testing recently? Where do you sit outside of meals?

Comment 6: As well as other advice mentioned by other people, ensure that you’re hydrated, it increases insulin production

Comment 7: I always food is my enemy. I try to eat few carbs per meal. More calories than carbs. Lots of salads. Always include a protein and peanut butter is your friend. My go to foods for eating out of course is a salad, a bacon egg and cheese biscuit, a McDonalds fish filet and a Whopper Junior and always a couple fries from someone’s meal LOL.

span_annotations.span: We need more info. It’s normal to spike after eating - and it depends where you started. If you need a breather, low carb = less insulin which = fewer spikes.
As well as other advice mentioned by other people, ensure that you’re hydrated, it increases insulin production

I always food is my enemy.   I try to eat few carbs per meal.  More calories than carbs.  Lots of salads.  Always include a protein and peanut butter is your friend.  My go to foods for eating out of course is a salad,  a bacon egg and cheese biscuit, a McDonalds fish filet and a Whopper Junior and always a couple fries from someone’s meal LOL.

displayed_text:
Post

Pump Prescription Can a primary care physician write a script for an Omnipod? I have a tandem pump now, but I can’t see my endocrinologist and I’d like to try to switch.

Comments:

Comment 1: I imagine they technically could, but a physician who is not managing your diabetes will probably be reluctant to prescribe it for you. Also, your insurance will probably not cover another pump until the warranty on your current one expires.

Comment 2: Is there a reason you can’t see your endo? You can bring it up with your primary care doc but I bet they would want to just refer you to the endo to handle it. If you have an endo you’ve seen before then I bet it’s likely your primary care could help be the middleman to send off requests to your endo.

Comment 3: Yeah they probably could but they'd also have to specify your pump settings. I think most PCPs would be somewhat reluctant to do that. This isn't like a CGM where the script just says Dexcom G6, they have to specify basal rate, carb ratio, etc, and I'm not sure a doctor who doesn't deal with pumps a lot would want to take responsibility for that. ​ Have you tried just messaging your Endo? If you're already on a pump I'm not sure you would really need a physical visit to be swapped to a different one. If you've seen them in the last year and are doing fine maybe they'd be ok just swapping things over based on your request?

Comment 4: I don’t have an endo and never have and my pcp prescribed both my tandem and the one for Omni pod 5 that I never used.

Comment 5: I’ve seen every endo that Kaiser has to offer in my area. They are useless. My endo of record is the chief of staff and she’s the worst of the lot. My pcp and I are a team and he prescribes all my medications and devices. With his help and willingness to trust me and experiment, my last a1c was 4.8 with 97% time in range.

Comment 6: Your Tandem pump is covered by DME. IF Omnipod is covered by your pharmacy plan, then you can actually get both. Yes, you need a separate prescription for the Omnipod starter kit and the pods, but it’s possible to do. That being said, you’re likely to have better luck with your endo than your PCP, but hard to say. You can always try your PCP and they may just use whatever settings are in your Tandem pump….but fair warning, those algorithms are VERY different.

span_annotations.span: I imagine they technically could, but a physician who is not managing your diabetes will probably be reluctant to prescribe it for you. Also, your insurance will probably not cover another pump until the warranty on your current one expires.

Yeah they probably could but they'd also have to specify your pump settings. I think most PCPs would be somewhat reluctant to do that. This isn't like a CGM where the script just says Dexcom G6, they have to specify basal rate, carb ratio, etc, and I'm not sure a doctor who doesn't deal with pumps a lot would want to take responsibility for that.

​

Have you tried just messaging your Endo? If you're already on a pump I'm not sure you would really need a physical visit to be swapped to a different one. If you've seen them in the last year and are doing fine maybe they'd be ok just swapping things over based on your request?
I don’t have an endo and never have and my pcp prescribed both my tandem and the one for Omni pod 5 that I never used.

Your Tandem pump is covered by DME. IF Omnipod is covered by your pharmacy plan, then you can actually get both. Yes, you need a separate prescription for the Omnipod starter kit and the pods, but it’s possible to do. 

That being said, you’re likely to have better luck with your endo than your PCP, but hard to say. You can always try your PCP and they may just use whatever settings are in your Tandem pump….but fair warning, those algorithms are VERY different.

Post

How do you all make meat heavy diets work? So I’m trying my hand at a meat heavy keto diet and IT IS NOT WORKING. As in, my bg has been at its highest in a while (300s) and resistant. Even if I inject to correct, my bg goes down for a bit and then goes back up. I think the resistance is due to the slow meat digestion and the high sugars due to the high calories? This is since dinner yesterday night, around 20 hours ago, where I ate just roasted beef ribs. I ate nothing this entire day, but caved out of hunger now and took metformin with my correction + bolus just in case. I am not in ketoacidosis. Is there something I’m missing or doing wrong? For context, I ate very little meat before but still had a high protein diet and my sugars were well controlled. I am stepping back and going back to my pea protein shakes in order to try and reset my body back to normal.

Comments:

Comment 1: I bolus for fat and protein following the math from the Warsaw method. https://waltzingthedragon.ca/diabetes/nutrition-excercise/reduce-post-meal-spikes-caused-by-fat-and-protein/

Comment 2: meat doesn’t have sugar as such but some people do need to bolus for protein. i usually don’t, so i count myself lucky. HOWEVER — you also shouldn’t go several hours/a full day without eating. your liver can start to pump out glucose because you still need energy. my best guess is this is what’s happening to you with your BG starting to drop then going back up.

Comment 3: Yeah, this is why the high protein kind of low carb never worked for me. Even when I bolus for protein and fat, it ultimately increases my insulin resistance, and I do much much better on moderate protein. A lot of people have that same experience. A lot of people don't. This is truly a very personal disease that every person kind of has to work out themselves. (And yeah, skipping meals and doing IF doesn't work for me either!)

Comment 4: My insulin requirements went haywire when I did really low carb. Seemed like whenever I thought I had the math right I needed more insulin the next time. Fat, protein, carbs, all had big insulin requirements.

Comment 5: Keto doesn’t usually work for T1D.. you typically end up with DKA.

Comment 6: I suggest you stop doing that. Obviously it’s not working for you and it’s really bad for your kidneys.

Comment 7: i don’t know enough on this topic but my endo has told me keto can be difficult for diabetics because if you eliminate carbs the second your body finally has some it becomes overly sensitive and will spike your blood sugar

Comment 8: Animal fats don't really agree with me so I would go really lean meats.

Comment 9: not to derail, but isn't metformin for type 2 diabetes? Did you put BBQ sauce on your ribs? You do have to bolus for protein, but not much. Try using the Carb Manager app. It will give your total carbs in a meal after you input the items. I am doing keto and BG has never been better.

span_annotations.span: I bolus for fat and protein following the math from the Warsaw method. https://waltzingthedragon.ca/diabetes/nutrition-excercise/reduce-post-meal-spikes-caused-by-fat-and-protein/

i don’t know enough on this topic but my endo has told me keto can be difficult for diabetics because if you eliminate carbs the second your body finally has some it becomes overly sensitive and will spike your blood sugar

Post

Can I actually drink milkshake? For valentines, my boyfriend and I went to McDonald's because we're two young men in our early twenties and late teens, and therefore, we are broke as fuck. It was still romantic, despite the one billion children in the restaurant. While deciding what to order, I came across milkshakes. And I haven't had a milkshake since 2017, when I was diagnosed with t1. My boyfriend asked me if I can actually drink that, since I've told him that I can't drink sugary stuff (unless they contain alcohol, hallelujah) and I realised I'd never asked my dietician about that. So I drank coke zero instead, and I'm getting really tired of that. So so SO tired of coke zero. Can I have milkshakes? Because honestly I miss milkshakes so much. They're my guilty pleasure. I need them back in my life. How do pen users take enough insulin for milkshakes? Is milkshake on the list of "forbidden snacks"? Please keep yourselves from preaching your low carb, keto, Mars soil only diets and whatnot. I'm struggling to stay above the underweight limit. A change in diet is not what I need right now. Thank you for your understanding.

Comments:

Comment 1: Rejoice! Drink a shake! Now, not all shakes are created equal. McDonald's vanilla shakes (small) tip the scale at nearly 80g of carbs! So, just be sure to calculate the appropriate units of your fast-acting insulin. And happy Valentine's Day to you and your boyfriend! ❤️🏳️‍🌈

Comment 2: how have you had diabetes for 3 years and not know that you can drink sugary things? you sweet summer child. you can have whatever you want as long as you count the carbs and take the correct amount of insulin!

Comment 3: Short answer. Yes... I use a pump so I handle milkshakes and stuff differently. But! For sugary drinks like that, if I had to inject, I would prebolus at least 20 minutes in advance. Then freely drink it. That way I make sure the insulin is acting in me and dropping me, at the same time stay in range by drinking the milkshake

Comment 4: Go ahead a splurge! Just make sure you dose for it. My son gets a treat once a month and it’s all trial and error. Some are harder to figure out than others but you won’t know until you try. Happy Valentines Day!

Comment 5: You came here to ask if you can have a milkshake but literally banned people against high sugar items from answering, so, you just wanted people to validate your decision, so drink the milkshake. Liquid sugar is extremely hard to bolus for you’re gonna need to watch yourself carefully. Good luck.

Comment 6: I remember feeling like that for the first few years after my diagnosis. Drink the milkshake, just monitor a little more than normal if you don’t have a cgm. You may need to take the insulin in split doses since you mentioned you are on pens, but you can responsibly have a milkshake.

Comment 7: Mini shakes from sonic are a serious weakness of mine - they’re small enough that the carb load isn’t too insane 👍

Comment 8: A traditional ice cream shake from McDonalds can be 60-100 grams of carbs: https://www.mcdonalds.com/us/en-us/product/vanilla-shake-large.html (toggle the sizes) can you? Yes. Do you want to eat 1/2-2/3 of your daily carb load in one item? It's not a good idea, but you can. Interestingly enough, because of the fat content, it will not spike as badly, but it will spike for longer (order of 5-6 hours as opposed to 2). Sugary soda (no fat) spikes it higher, faster - in some ways, it is more dangerous.

span_annotations.span: Rejoice! Drink a shake! Now, not all shakes are created equal. McDonald's vanilla shakes (small) tip the scale at nearly 80g of carbs! So, just be sure to calculate the appropriate units of your fast-acting insulin. And happy Valentine's Day to you and your boyfriend! ❤️🏳️‍🌈

displayed_text:
Post

How to Increase Insulin Sensitivity I have been noticing that i need more insulin for the same food Since some time How to improve insulin sensitivity

Comments:

Comment 1: Exercise, weightloss, and/ or muscle gain. That said, insulin needs change. Is there a reason you are concerned about the amount you need?

Comment 2: Keto or low carb diets will cause some insulin resistance if that's how you're eating. If that's the case, you can add in carbs every once in a while to combat this. Check out carb cycling. As always, the cleaner the carbs, the better. Shoot for whole foods, veggies and berries. Eating "cleaner", more whole foods, will help a little in general. The rest has been covered, exercise, more muscle, less fat.

Comment 3: im going to give you the best answer.... ready? here: How does resistance training benefit diabetics ? So by now you should know that everything you eat turns into glucose or “sugar” right? Well, our muscles store and are made of glucose and our bodies use this glucose for energy. What happens when we start building muscle ? The food we eat (glucose) will have a place to go, where does it go ? It goes directly to these muscles instead of just staying in the bloodstream and going nowhere. This is why resistance training improves insulin sensitivity. you can read full post here on my blog: https://www.dieabeast.com/weight-training-benefits-for-diabetics/ lift some weights mate....

Comment 4: How old are you and how long have you been diagnosed? If it is less than 1-2 years, then you may just be finally getting over the honeymoon phase. It is pretty normal for needs to change over time, especially as your body matures.

Comment 5: I also experienced this as winter started and I stopped exercising / eating as healthy. Active lifestyle lowers my insulin needs

Comment 6: If you can do some intermittent fasting, it may help you. You could start small w/not snacking after dinner then eating breakfast an hour later-

Comment 7: Reduce fats (especially saturated). No oils. Couple that with whole foods and some exercise and you're gold!

displayed_text:
Post

How much insulin do you take on average? And how much is considered a “normal range”? Genuinely curious about this one. I’ve been type 1 for almost 4 years now, and still learning more about it everyday. A little backstory as to why I’m interested in this question; since I’ve been diagnosed with t1, I’ve been hospitalized with DKA a few times. Each time the hospital treats it and later give me food and insulin, they would only give me like 4-6 units of insulin with my meals. My normal dosage outside of the hospital is like 12-14. Is there a reason the hospital would only give me very little? The last time I was treated in the hospital I spoke up about it and told them that I needed more insulin or my blood sugar would just go up again. Has anything similar happened to you?

Comments:

Comment 1: The way it works is generally like this - if your endocrinologist or whoever writes your prescription for insulin isn’t consulted and therefore isn’t putting in orders, the attending hospitalist or the endo on call uses a formula based on the range of your age and weight to determine your dose and correction factor/sliding scale.

Comment 2: I haven't experienced anything like that, but I usually average 40 units a day, and I just switched pumps, and had to up my basal 60 percent, so I think a normal range depends on the diabetic?

Comment 3: An acquaintance nurse tells me that sliding scale is a normal practice since the majority of diabetic patients they have are type 2. It seems really dumb that people with access to experts wouldn't try harder but healthcare in America is generally not great.

Comment 4: That’s odd though, the times my son has gone in, they always ask what his carb/ratio is and they go by it. He’s 1:10

Comment 5: The sliding scale ratio is to prevent your body from going into shock. If your coming off DKA bringing back your normal bg range should be done slowly rather than all at once. If it were treated all at once and your body did go into shock you would feel low symptoms for high bgs. I asked about this when I went into DKA and my nurse was amazing with helping me understand what was happening and walked me through the process of my treatment. I have been a type 1 diabetic for 3 years now and have kept it under control for the most part. I find if I'm having a high day to have less carbs and if I spike I will go for a run or throw on a workout video from youtube to help me bring it down. It's mostly knowing what your body needs and finding a balance with your ratios that work for you. I would talk to your doctor about switching ratios with your long acting insulin rather than increasing your meal time insulin if your usually high before meals and are doing a lot of correcting.

Comment 6: My opinion - endos can be trusted to give a decent starting point for basal and bolus doses, but it’s up to each of us to really dial it in properly. My endo started me at 4 units twice a day. I ran experiments from Bernstein’s book, and ended up at 10 evening and 4 morning. At random times, he’s suggested more or less, but I do my own experiments and trust my judgement over his. He spends about 5 minutes a year looking my data. I spend that much a day. Probably more.

Comment 7: I use carb to insulin ratio and it varies by time of day and what's going on in my life : in am 20:1 ; afternoon 40:1 and after 6ish 50:1 - we are all different, have different amount of remaining beta cell function, type of diet etc. This is why we are a flexible, ride the wave and enjoy the trip group.

Comment 8: I’m on 36 lantus and 20-40 on average on humalog per day.

span_annotations.span: The sliding scale ratio is to prevent your body from going into shock. If your coming off DKA bringing back your normal bg range should be done slowly rather than all at once. If it were treated all at once and your body did go into shock you would feel low symptoms for high bgs. I asked about this when I went into DKA and my nurse was amazing with helping me understand what was happening and walked me through the process of my treatment. I have been a type 1 diabetic for 3 years now and have kept it under control for the most part. I find if I'm having a high day to have less carbs and if I spike I will go for a run or throw on a workout video from youtube to help me bring it down. It's mostly knowing what your body needs and finding a balance with your ratios that work for you. I would talk to your doctor about switching ratios with your long acting insulin rather than increasing your meal time insulin if your usually high before meals and are doing a lot of correcting.

displayed_text:
Post

How to stop spikes Every single time I eat damn near anything I spike very quickly, the issue is is that when I spike I don’t come back down like at all. So all I can do is just sit and watch my blood sugar go up. I feel like I would have to starve myself in order to keep my blood sugars at a level I feel ok at. What’s something you guys do to avoid the spikes after eating?

Comments:

Comment 1: Take a walk.

Comment 2: I can’t always avoid them but I find the timing is important-I have a list of things I know how long to pre bolus for or extend my bolus. So somethings I get right but some no. If I find I’m not coming down then correction doses.

Comment 3: What time did you bolus vs what time did you eat? What is your blood sugar 4hrs post injection(for the meal)? What did you eat? Did you weigh it or guesstimate the carb content? How does your blood sugar get back in range? Do you have to give a correction bolus to get back in range? 🫶💙

Comment 4: We need more info. It’s normal to spike after eating - and it depends where you started. If you need a breather, low carb = less insulin which = fewer spikes.

Comment 5: Judging by that graph, you’re running fairly high the entire time. Have you done basal testing recently? Where do you sit outside of meals?

Comment 6: As well as other advice mentioned by other people, ensure that you’re hydrated, it increases insulin production

Comment 7: I always food is my enemy. I try to eat few carbs per meal. More calories than carbs. Lots of salads. Always include a protein and peanut butter is your friend. My go to foods for eating out of course is a salad, a bacon egg and cheese biscuit, a McDonalds fish filet and a Whopper Junior and always a couple fries from someone’s meal LOL.

Post

Pump Prescription Can a primary care physician write a script for an Omnipod? I have a tandem pump now, but I can’t see my endocrinologist and I’d like to try to switch.

Comments:

Comment 1: I imagine they technically could, but a physician who is not managing your diabetes will probably be reluctant to prescribe it for you. Also, your insurance will probably not cover another pump until the warranty on your current one expires.

Comment 2: Is there a reason you can’t see your endo? You can bring it up with your primary care doc but I bet they would want to just refer you to the endo to handle it. If you have an endo you’ve seen before then I bet it’s likely your primary care could help be the middleman to send off requests to your endo.

Comment 3: Yeah they probably could but they'd also have to specify your pump settings. I think most PCPs would be somewhat reluctant to do that. This isn't like a CGM where the script just says Dexcom G6, they have to specify basal rate, carb ratio, etc, and I'm not sure a doctor who doesn't deal with pumps a lot would want to take responsibility for that. ​ Have you tried just messaging your Endo? If you're already on a pump I'm not sure you would really need a physical visit to be swapped to a different one. If you've seen them in the last year and are doing fine maybe they'd be ok just swapping things over based on your request?

Comment 4: I don’t have an endo and never have and my pcp prescribed both my tandem and the one for Omni pod 5 that I never used.

Comment 5: I’ve seen every endo that Kaiser has to offer in my area. They are useless. My endo of record is the chief of staff and she’s the worst of the lot. My pcp and I are a team and he prescribes all my medications and devices. With his help and willingness to trust me and experiment, my last a1c was 4.8 with 97% time in range.

Comment 6: Your Tandem pump is covered by DME. IF Omnipod is covered by your pharmacy plan, then you can actually get both. Yes, you need a separate prescription for the Omnipod starter kit and the pods, but it’s possible to do. That being said, you’re likely to have better luck with your endo than your PCP, but hard to say. You can always try your PCP and they may just use whatever settings are in your Tandem pump….but fair warning, those algorithms are VERY different.

Post

How to store my insulin while going on a trip? Im planing with my boyfriend to go on a trip for a whole month, mostly camping but i dont know whats the best way to keep my insulin in a cold enviroment. Do you have any recomendation for a good portable cooler??

Comments:

Comment 1: Frio packs EDIT: I took Frio wallets up Mt Kilimanjaro and they kept my insulin at the right temperature even when faced with sub zero at night and 30°C at sea level, and all you need to refresh/recharge them is some water - just dunk them

Comment 2: I have a Dometic cooler. It can be powered off of different power sources and has more precise temperature control than a mini fridge. Good for both travel and for an emergency. Also, make sure your Rx is up to date before your trip. That way, if you need an emergency refill, it will be easier to get.

Comment 3: Insulin is shelf stable for about a month at room temp. It will lose a bit of potency (5%ish max) over the month, but it’s no different from having a vial of R and NPH in an old style kit. Bring enough alcohol swabs to ensure clean tops and clean sites. Avoid keeping insulin in the sun and try to keep it’s bag in the shade. I’ve used something like a men’s night bag, similar to a toiletries bag but usually leather or heavy cloth to protect from shaving razors. It might be a good idea to put insulin in it’s own ziplock inside of whatever bag you end up using. In fact, it might be worth putting all medical supplies in a water tight ziplock inside the bag as a precaution. Annoying to open is better than infections from pond water logged supplies. Good luck!

Comment 4: You can get insulin coolers on amazon

Comment 5: I take out a bottle and keep it out of the fridge for a month. No issues for the past 5years

Comment 6: Where in the world are you going? What month of the year? Unopened insulin is pretty hardy, and in the right environment will store a long time.

span_annotations.span: I took Frio wallets up Mt Kilimanjaro and they kept my insulin at the right temperature even when faced with sub zero at night and 30°C at sea level,
Insulin is shelf stable for about a month at room temp. It will lose a bit of potency (5%ish max) over the month, but it’s no different from having a vial of R and NPH in an old style kit.

displayed_text:
Post

How do you all make meat heavy diets work? So I’m trying my hand at a meat heavy keto diet and IT IS NOT WORKING. As in, my bg has been at its highest in a while (300s) and resistant. Even if I inject to correct, my bg goes down for a bit and then goes back up. I think the resistance is due to the slow meat digestion and the high sugars due to the high calories? This is since dinner yesterday night, around 20 hours ago, where I ate just roasted beef ribs. I ate nothing this entire day, but caved out of hunger now and took metformin with my correction + bolus just in case. I am not in ketoacidosis. Is there something I’m missing or doing wrong? For context, I ate very little meat before but still had a high protein diet and my sugars were well controlled. I am stepping back and going back to my pea protein shakes in order to try and reset my body back to normal.

Comments:

Comment 1: I bolus for fat and protein following the math from the Warsaw method. https://waltzingthedragon.ca/diabetes/nutrition-excercise/reduce-post-meal-spikes-caused-by-fat-and-protein/

Comment 2: meat doesn’t have sugar as such but some people do need to bolus for protein. i usually don’t, so i count myself lucky. HOWEVER — you also shouldn’t go several hours/a full day without eating. your liver can start to pump out glucose because you still need energy. my best guess is this is what’s happening to you with your BG starting to drop then going back up.

Comment 3: Yeah, this is why the high protein kind of low carb never worked for me. Even when I bolus for protein and fat, it ultimately increases my insulin resistance, and I do much much better on moderate protein. A lot of people have that same experience. A lot of people don't. This is truly a very personal disease that every person kind of has to work out themselves. (And yeah, skipping meals and doing IF doesn't work for me either!)

Comment 4: My insulin requirements went haywire when I did really low carb. Seemed like whenever I thought I had the math right I needed more insulin the next time. Fat, protein, carbs, all had big insulin requirements.

Comment 5: Keto doesn’t usually work for T1D.. you typically end up with DKA.

Comment 6: I suggest you stop doing that. Obviously it’s not working for you and it’s really bad for your kidneys.

Comment 7: i don’t know enough on this topic but my endo has told me keto can be difficult for diabetics because if you eliminate carbs the second your body finally has some it becomes overly sensitive and will spike your blood sugar

Comment 8: Animal fats don't really agree with me so I would go really lean meats.

Comment 9: not to derail, but isn't metformin for type 2 diabetes? Did you put BBQ sauce on your ribs? You do have to bolus for protein, but not much. Try using the Carb Manager app. It will give your total carbs in a meal after you input the items. I am doing keto and BG has never been better.

span_annotations.span: I bolus for fat and protein following the math from the Warsaw method. https://waltzingthedragon.ca/diabetes/nutrition-excercise/reduce-post-meal-spikes-caused-by-fat-and-protein/
you also shouldn’t go several hours/a full day without eating. your liver can start to pump out glucose because you still need energy.

My insulin requirements went haywire when I did really low carb. Seemed like whenever I thought I had the math right I needed more insulin the next time. Fat, protein, carbs, all had big insulin requirements.
my endo has told me keto can be difficult for diabetics because if you eliminate carbs the second your body finally has some it becomes overly sensitive and will spike your blood sugar
You do have to bolus for protein, but not much. Try using the Carb Manager app. It will give your total carbs in a meal after you input the items. I am doing keto and BG has never been better.

displayed_text:
Post

Can I actually drink milkshake? For valentines, my boyfriend and I went to McDonald's because we're two young men in our early twenties and late teens, and therefore, we are broke as fuck. It was still romantic, despite the one billion children in the restaurant. While deciding what to order, I came across milkshakes. And I haven't had a milkshake since 2017, when I was diagnosed with t1. My boyfriend asked me if I can actually drink that, since I've told him that I can't drink sugary stuff (unless they contain alcohol, hallelujah) and I realised I'd never asked my dietician about that. So I drank coke zero instead, and I'm getting really tired of that. So so SO tired of coke zero. Can I have milkshakes? Because honestly I miss milkshakes so much. They're my guilty pleasure. I need them back in my life. How do pen users take enough insulin for milkshakes? Is milkshake on the list of "forbidden snacks"? Please keep yourselves from preaching your low carb, keto, Mars soil only diets and whatnot. I'm struggling to stay above the underweight limit. A change in diet is not what I need right now. Thank you for your understanding.

Comments:

Comment 1: Rejoice! Drink a shake! Now, not all shakes are created equal. McDonald's vanilla shakes (small) tip the scale at nearly 80g of carbs! So, just be sure to calculate the appropriate units of your fast-acting insulin. And happy Valentine's Day to you and your boyfriend! ❤️🏳️‍🌈

Comment 2: how have you had diabetes for 3 years and not know that you can drink sugary things? you sweet summer child. you can have whatever you want as long as you count the carbs and take the correct amount of insulin!

Comment 3: Short answer. Yes... I use a pump so I handle milkshakes and stuff differently. But! For sugary drinks like that, if I had to inject, I would prebolus at least 20 minutes in advance. Then freely drink it. That way I make sure the insulin is acting in me and dropping me, at the same time stay in range by drinking the milkshake

Comment 4: Go ahead a splurge! Just make sure you dose for it. My son gets a treat once a month and it’s all trial and error. Some are harder to figure out than others but you won’t know until you try. Happy Valentines Day!

Comment 5: You came here to ask if you can have a milkshake but literally banned people against high sugar items from answering, so, you just wanted people to validate your decision, so drink the milkshake. Liquid sugar is extremely hard to bolus for you’re gonna need to watch yourself carefully. Good luck.

Comment 6: I remember feeling like that for the first few years after my diagnosis. Drink the milkshake, just monitor a little more than normal if you don’t have a cgm. You may need to take the insulin in split doses since you mentioned you are on pens, but you can responsibly have a milkshake.

Comment 7: Mini shakes from sonic are a serious weakness of mine - they’re small enough that the carb load isn’t too insane 👍

Comment 8: A traditional ice cream shake from McDonalds can be 60-100 grams of carbs: https://www.mcdonalds.com/us/en-us/product/vanilla-shake-large.html (toggle the sizes) can you? Yes. Do you want to eat 1/2-2/3 of your daily carb load in one item? It's not a good idea, but you can. Interestingly enough, because of the fat content, it will not spike as badly, but it will spike for longer (order of 5-6 hours as opposed to 2). Sugary soda (no fat) spikes it higher, faster - in some ways, it is more dangerous.

span_annotations.span: Liquid sugar is extremely hard to bolus for you’re gonna need to watch yourself carefully.

Do you want to eat 1/2-2/3 of your daily carb load in one item? It's not a good idea, but you can. 

Interestingly enough, because of the fat content, it will not spike as badly, but it will spike for longer (order of 5-6 hours as opposed to 2). Sugary soda (no fat) spikes it higher, faster - in some ways, it is more dangerous.

displayed_text:
Post

How to Increase Insulin Sensitivity I have been noticing that i need more insulin for the same food Since some time How to improve insulin sensitivity

Comments:

Comment 1: Exercise, weightloss, and/ or muscle gain. That said, insulin needs change. Is there a reason you are concerned about the amount you need?

Comment 2: Keto or low carb diets will cause some insulin resistance if that's how you're eating. If that's the case, you can add in carbs every once in a while to combat this. Check out carb cycling. As always, the cleaner the carbs, the better. Shoot for whole foods, veggies and berries. Eating "cleaner", more whole foods, will help a little in general. The rest has been covered, exercise, more muscle, less fat.

Comment 3: im going to give you the best answer.... ready? here: How does resistance training benefit diabetics ? So by now you should know that everything you eat turns into glucose or “sugar” right? Well, our muscles store and are made of glucose and our bodies use this glucose for energy. What happens when we start building muscle ? The food we eat (glucose) will have a place to go, where does it go ? It goes directly to these muscles instead of just staying in the bloodstream and going nowhere. This is why resistance training improves insulin sensitivity. you can read full post here on my blog: https://www.dieabeast.com/weight-training-benefits-for-diabetics/ lift some weights mate....

Comment 4: How old are you and how long have you been diagnosed? If it is less than 1-2 years, then you may just be finally getting over the honeymoon phase. It is pretty normal for needs to change over time, especially as your body matures.

Comment 5: I also experienced this as winter started and I stopped exercising / eating as healthy. Active lifestyle lowers my insulin needs

Comment 6: If you can do some intermittent fasting, it may help you. You could start small w/not snacking after dinner then eating breakfast an hour later-

Comment 7: Reduce fats (especially saturated). No oils. Couple that with whole foods and some exercise and you're gold!

span_annotations.span:
Keto or low carb diets will cause some insulin resistance if that's how you're eating.  If that's the case, you can add in carbs every once in a while to combat this.  Check out carb cycling.  As always, the cleaner the carbs, the better.  Shoot for whole foods, veggies and berries.  

Eating "cleaner", more whole foods, will help a little in general.  The rest has been covered, exercise, more muscle, less fat.

This is why resistance training improves insulin sensitivity.

you can read full post here on my blog: https://www.dieabeast.com/weight-training-benefits-for-diabetics/

lift some weights mate....
I also experienced this as winter started and I stopped exercising / eating as healthy. Active lifestyle lowers my insulin needs
If you can do some intermittent fasting, it may help you.

Reduce fats (especially saturated). No oils.

Couple that with whole foods and some exercise and you're gold!

displayed_text:
Post

how do you get tested for type 1 or type 2?

Comments:

Comment 1: Have y'all had C-peptide and HbA1c tests done? Those are the standard diagnostic tests.

Comment 2: They tested for GAD65 antibodies for me to confirm it’s type 1

Comment 3: I got an antibody test done and confirmed type 1. Although apparently symptoms for type 1 and type 2 can have some variation so they could also be doing that.

Comment 4: She needs to be seen by an endocrinologist. I was initially diagnosed by a family practice doc as T2 even though both my mother and my son are T1. Turns out I have LADA which is an autoimmune type that progresses slower than standard T1 and usually appears after age 30. I had a c peptide done initially and my results were within the normal range despite a high A1C and fasting glucose of over 300. Once I saw an endocrinologist I was immediately started on insulin and tested for GAD and Islet antibodies. Please have her ask for a referral as some types of oral meds can actually speed up the destruction of beta cells in autoimmune diabetes. EDIT: I had the same problem with getting in to an endocrinologist even with my GP’s referral. I couldn’t get an appointment until like 4 months out! A fantastic receptionist suggested I call at least weekly to check for any cancelations. I ended up getting in two weeks later. This route might be worth a shot. EDIT #2: If she does request a c peptide and the results come back normal they can still be interpreted for type. T2’s often have an elevated or high normal c peptide level whereas autoimmune tends to be low or low normal. Feel free to message me; I’m happy to help in any way I can.

Comment 5: I don’t really know about type 2... but as a type-1 I remember that they took a blood sample cause I had severe head aches for about a week or so. Then they told me that I could go home and they would call me. The next morning they called me and said right as I was going to eat breakfast that I should get there ASAP and I shouldn’t eat anything and from there on they just took an HbA1C

Comment 6: They need to run a full metabolic panel, c-peptide, and GAD antibody tests. If the doctor refuses, make sure to ask that they document their refusal in her chart. Never ever be afraid to ask for a second opinion.

span_annotations.span: Turns out I have LADA which is an autoimmune type that progresses slower than standard T1 and usually appears after age 30

How much insulin do you take on average? And how much is considered a “normal range”? Genuinely curious about this one. I’ve been type 1 for almost 4 years now, and still learning more about it everyday. A little backstory as to why I’m interested in this question; since I’ve been diagnosed with t1, I’ve been hospitalized with DKA a few times. Each time the hospital treats it and later give me food and insulin, they would only give me like 4-6 units of insulin with my meals. My normal dosage outside of the hospital is like 12-14. Is there a reason the hospital would only give me very little? The last time I was treated in the hospital I spoke up about it and told them that I needed more insulin or my blood sugar would just go up again. Has anything similar happened to you?

Comments:

Comment 1: The way it works is generally like this - if your endocrinologist or whoever writes your prescription for insulin isn’t consulted and therefore isn’t putting in orders, the attending hospitalist or the endo on call uses a formula based on the range of your age and weight to determine your dose and correction factor/sliding scale.

Comment 2: I haven't experienced anything like that, but I usually average 40 units a day, and I just switched pumps, and had to up my basal 60 percent, so I think a normal range depends on the diabetic?

Comment 3: An acquaintance nurse tells me that sliding scale is a normal practice since the majority of diabetic patients they have are type 2. It seems really dumb that people with access to experts wouldn't try harder but healthcare in America is generally not great.

Comment 4: That’s odd though, the times my son has gone in, they always ask what his carb/ratio is and they go by it. He’s 1:10

Comment 5: The sliding scale ratio is to prevent your body from going into shock. If your coming off DKA bringing back your normal bg range should be done slowly rather than all at once. If it were treated all at once and your body did go into shock you would feel low symptoms for high bgs. I asked about this when I went into DKA and my nurse was amazing with helping me understand what was happening and walked me through the process of my treatment. I have been a type 1 diabetic for 3 years now and have kept it under control for the most part. I find if I'm having a high day to have less carbs and if I spike I will go for a run or throw on a workout video from youtube to help me bring it down. It's mostly knowing what your body needs and finding a balance with your ratios that work for you. I would talk to your doctor about switching ratios with your long acting insulin rather than increasing your meal time insulin if your usually high before meals and are doing a lot of correcting.

Comment 6: My opinion - endos can be trusted to give a decent starting point for basal and bolus doses, but it’s up to each of us to really dial it in properly. My endo started me at 4 units twice a day. I ran experiments from Bernstein’s book, and ended up at 10 evening and 4 morning. At random times, he’s suggested more or less, but I do my own experiments and trust my judgement over his. He spends about 5 minutes a year looking my data. I spend that much a day. Probably more.

Comment 7: I use carb to insulin ratio and it varies by time of day and what's going on in my life : in am 20:1 ; afternoon 40:1 and after 6ish 50:1 - we are all different, have different amount of remaining beta cell function, type of diet etc. This is why we are a flexible, ride the wave and enjoy the trip group.

Comment 8: I’m on 36 lantus and 20-40 on average on humalog per day.

So all I can do is just sit and watch my blood sugar go up. I feel like I would have to starve myself in order to keep my blood sugars at a level I feel ok at. What’s something you guys do to avoid the spikes after eating?

Comment 2: I can’t always avoid them but I find the timing is important-I have a list of things I know how long to pre bolus for or extend my bolus. So somethings I get right but some no. If I find I’m not coming down then correction doses.

Post

Pump Prescription Can a primary care physician write a script for an Omnipod? I have a tandem pump now, but I can’t see my endocrinologist and I’d like to try to switch.

Comments:

Comment 1: I imagine they technically could, but a physician who is not managing your diabetes will probably be reluctant to prescribe it for you. Also, your insurance will probably not cover another pump until the warranty on your current one expires.

Comment 2: Is there a reason you can’t see your endo? You can bring it up with your primary care doc but I bet they would want to just refer you to the endo to handle it. If you have an endo you’ve seen before then I bet it’s likely your primary care could help be the middleman to send off requests to your endo.

Comment 3: Yeah they probably could but they'd also have to specify your pump settings. I think most PCPs would be somewhat reluctant to do that. This isn't like a CGM where the script just says Dexcom G6, they have to specify basal rate, carb ratio, etc, and I'm not sure a doctor who doesn't deal with pumps a lot would want to take responsibility for that. ​ Have you tried just messaging your Endo? If you're already on a pump I'm not sure you would really need a physical visit to be swapped to a different one. If you've seen them in the last year and are doing fine maybe they'd be ok just swapping things over based on your request?

Comment 4: I don’t have an endo and never have and my pcp prescribed both my tandem and the one for Omni pod 5 that I never used.

Comment 5: I’ve seen every endo that Kaiser has to offer in my area. They are useless. My endo of record is the chief of staff and she’s the worst of the lot. My pcp and I are a team and he prescribes all my medications and devices. With his help and willingness to trust me and experiment, my last a1c was 4.8 with 97% time in range.

Comment 6: Your Tandem pump is covered by DME. IF Omnipod is covered by your pharmacy plan, then you can actually get both. Yes, you need a separate prescription for the Omnipod starter kit and the pods, but it’s possible to do. That being said, you’re likely to have better luck with your endo than your PCP, but hard to say. You can always try your PCP and they may just use whatever settings are in your Tandem pump….but fair warning, those algorithms are VERY different.
